docs.lead_paragraph: Magellan Health Services Inc. said yesterday that it would buy the closely held Merit Behavioral Care Corporation for $460 million in cash. It will also assume $475 million in debt. Merit, based in Park Ridge, N.J., provides mental health and substance-abuse services and employee assistance programs to more than 21 million people at 800 clients. Its clients include private employers, union trusts, insurance carriers, health maintenance organizations and governments. Atlanta-based Magellan said it would account for the acquisition as a purchase, which means the company will have to write off Merit's good will, or intangible assets, over time.

docs.lead_paragraph: Oxford Health Plans, the big New York area health plan that has been invoked as an industry model for its ability to keep costs down while satisfying patients, said yesterday that it had been losing money because it fell behind in sending bills to customers and underestimated how much it owed doctors and hospitals. Because of the problems, the company faced the choice of whether to raise premiums more than expected -- perhaps angering the corporate customers with which it contracts -- or to take a big writeoff.

headline.main: Billing Problem Leads to Losses For Big H.M.O.

docs.lead_paragraph: Senate Republicans are holding up action on President Clinton's nominee to run the Medicare program in an effort to force Mr. Clinton to let doctors sign private contracts with affluent elderly patients willing to pay more than the fees set by Medicare. Senator Jon Kyl, Republican of Arizona, said that he had placed a ''hold'' on the nominee, Nancy-Ann Min DeParle, as a way to pressure the Administration. Mr. Kyl said he wanted the White House to accept his bill letting doctors negotiate private contracts with Medicare beneficiaries. Under such contracts, doctors would not be bound by Medicare's fee limits, but could charge whatever patients were willing to pay.

docs.lead_paragraph: Last week, the House of Representatives took time out from beating up the Internal Revenue Service to approve a fresh tax loophole. The proposal would authorize households to use up to $2,500 of after-tax money to establish ''school'' accounts, whose earnings would be tax free if used for certain education-related purposes. Lots of silly numbers were thrown around during the debate, but common sense tells us that the measure's promise for most taxpayers isn't just hollow, it's trivial. For the 80 percent of families with incomes of less than $50,000 a year, the payoff in tax savings would probably be a princely $15 a year or less -- not much of a down payment on the private school tuition, home computers and such that would be among the permitted uses for the money. Indeed, $15 won't even buy a school uniform.

docs.lead_paragraph: For most of this year, the New Jersey gubernatorial race sputtered along with little drama. Early surveys showed Gov. Christine Todd Whitman ahead, helped by the state's improved economy, the drop in crime and welfare rolls and, not least, her record of cutting taxes as she promised four years ago. Lately, James McGreevey, a State Senator and the Mayor of Woodbridge, has gained, hammering the Governor over school standards, soaring property taxes and auto insurance rates. Mrs. Whitman, a rising star in the Republican firmament a few years ago, is fighting back hard in a tight race that is drawing national attention. Today we endorse Mrs. Whitman for re-election, though the choice was not easy. Mrs. Whitman is an impressive politician with an excellent command of issues. But her 30 percent income-tax cut, which we opposed, has damaged the state's fiscal health because it was largely financed by a raid on the state pension systems. Mrs. Whitman compounded the error this year with a $2.7 billion bond issue to keep the pension system solvent. On the other hand, the Governor has compiled a solid record on the environment and education issues. Her approach to helping people on welfare find work has been humane. She has championed abortion rights, affirmative action and other causes of the moderate wing of the Republican Party. If she wins, she can help her party get beyond its punitive agenda in Washington.

docs.lead_paragraph: The ''bill of rights'' for patients that was tentatively approved last week by a Presidential commission would, if adopted by Congress, build in sensible consumer protections without strangling health plans with innovation-killing rules. There are important holes in the commission's work, but on the whole its draft is promising. The rise of managed care has brought innovative coverage and a surprisingly swift deceleration of health care inflation. But managed care imposes obstacles to choosing doctors and treatments and can reward plans that skimp on care. The insecurity surrounding managed care has triggered calls for Government action, and Congress is inundated with ill-conceived bills that would dictate how health plans treat patients. President Clinton deftly cut off the rush to legislate by appointing the commission, which will reconvene in November to adopt a final report.
